page.title: 17Lady Gibberd's Garden
page.content:
{Lady Gibberd's}house is in Marsh Lane. The garden covers 7 acres.{Pincey's {Brook,}a tributary of the{River Stort, runs through the garden.
{Sir Frederick Gibberd}designed the garden to hold statues and sculptures which he used to buy to help young artists. The garden also has many fountains.
Near the brook is a model fort made from the trunks of elm trees which had died from Dutch Elm Disease. Sir Frederick built the fort for his grandchildren.
{Lady Gibberd} opens the garden to the public each year to raise money for charity.
